Description: Linen bag containing a sample of halite crystals, i.e. salt (sodium chloride, NaCl).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: John de Monins Johnson
Curator's comments: Published in: Regulski, I. (ed.), 2022. Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt, p. 215

See Cartwright 2011. Halite deposits from, for example, the shore-line evaporation of Holocene lakes in the Fayum and the Wadi Natrun, were exploited for the collection of natron used in the preparation of burials through the early Islamic period. Nevertheless, as Johnson’s excavations were concentrated in the town’s rubbish heaps––and not the cemeteries of Antinoupolis––it is more likely that this material was destined for consumption or food processing (e.g., salting meat) rather than funerary purposes. Cartwright, C. R. 2011. Identification of the contents of three linen bags from El-Sheikh Ibada, Egypt. British Museum Analytical Request Report 2011/54 [unpublished]. London.
Bibliographic references: O'Connell et al 2014 / Antinoupolis at the British Museum (43)
Exhibition history: 2022-2023 13 Oct-19 Feb, London, BM, Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt
